instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fake charging
threads.message: so this board will charge white the computer is off.  Light comes on and os says the charger is plugged in.  however the battery drains.  He came in with a fake charger, so pretty sure that killed it.  Where to start on this guy?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fake charging
threads.message: Tried known good battery and/or DC in board? If so, post resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> as well as voltage on PPBUS without the battery

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fake charging
threads.message:
17/18/ - 3 ohms
27/28 - 2.02

These values are correct no?  I tried a good magsafe, but not battery.  Have to order one, do you think this could be caused by a battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fake charging
threads.message: 20.2 ohms or 2.02 kohms? If 20.2 ohms, try another battery first. Bad battery will obviously not charge. Voltage on PPBUS without the battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fake charging
threads.message:
2.02khoms sorry, my bad.

Computer will not turn on without battery. keeps resetting after 2-3 seconds.

ppbus is 12.57v then drops to 10.8v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fake charging
threads.message:
That's the problem 2.02 kohms is way way way off. There are a few possibilities here:

1. <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> is blown
2. <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> is blown (both could be blown as well)
3.<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> is blown (unlikely but possible)
4. The traces between the ISL and <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/2 are blown OR between <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/2 and <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> are blown.

Also a good idea to replace the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> when you figure out which of the above are true.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fake charging
threads.message: okay both <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> was blown.  bad <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> as well.  all is fixed :)  computer is turning on without battery now!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fake charging
